tit.e: Kujaku Myoo (peacock king of those who hold knowledge)
tit.cmt: 孔雀明王（くじゃくみょうおう）→Kujaku Myoo, peacock king of those who hold knowledge[http://www.aisf.or.jp/%7Ejaanus/]
tit.e: Kujaku Myoo (the peacock king of those who hold knowledge)
Kujaku Myoo (the peacock king of those who hold knowledge)

sen.j: 孔雀明王（くじゃくみょうおう）は、仏教の信仰対象であり、密教特有の尊格である明王のひとつ。
sen.e: Kujaku Myoo is a the object of worship in Buddhism and one of Myoo, Sonkaku peculiar to Mikkyo (Esoteric Buddhism).
sen.cmt: 密教→Mikkyo, Esoteric Buddhism[http://www.koyasan.or.jp/english/shingonshu/mikkyo.html] 尊格→Sonkaku [定訳不明]
sen.e: Kujaku Myoo is an object of worship in Buddhism and one of the Myoo (Sonkaku) peculiar to Mikkyo (Esoteric Buddhism).
Kujaku Myoo is an object of worship in Buddhism and one of the Myoo (king of wisdom) having venerable status specific to Mikkyo (Esoteric Buddhism).
sen.cmt: 明王の説明として (king of wisdom) を追加しました。 尊格の説明は、愛染明王のものと統一しました。

sen.j: 衆生を利益する徳を表すとされる。
sen.e: She is believed to represent the dharma of benefiting living things.
sen.cmt: 衆生→living things, the people[Webster Online Dictionary]
sen.e: She is believed to represent the dharma of benefit to living things.
She is believed to represent the dharma of benefit to living things.

sen.j: 元来はインドの女神マハーマユリーで、パーンチャ・ラクシャー（五守護女神）の一柱。
sen.e: Originally she is Mahamayuri, indian goddess, and one of Pancharakshya (Five Protectress Deities).
sen.cmt: パーンチャ・ラクシャー→Pancharakshya[http://www.shakyastatues.com/statue/fiveprotectressdeities]五守護女神→Five Protectress Deities[http://www.shakyastatues.com/statue/fiveprotectressdeities]
sen.e: Originally, she was Mahamayuri, an Indian goddess, and one of the Pancharakshya (five protector deities).
Originally, she was Mahamayuri, an Indian goddess, and one of the Pancharakshya (five protector deities).

sen.j: 梵語名マハーマーユーリー(Mahamayuri)は「偉大な孔雀」の意。
sen.e: Sanskrit name Mahamayuri means "great peacock".
Sanskrit name Mahamayuri means "great peacock."
Sanskrit name Mahamayuri means 'great peacock.'

sen.j: 摩訶摩瑜利(まかまゆり)、孔雀仏母、孔雀王母菩薩、金色孔雀王とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: She is also called Makamayuri, Kujaku Butsumo, Kujaku Omo Bosatsu or Konjiki kujaku-o.
sen.cmt: 摩訶摩瑜利(まかまゆり)→Makamayuri孔雀仏母→Kujaku Butsumo[http://www.aisf.or.jp/%7Ejaanus/]孔雀王母菩薩→Kujaku Butsumo Bosatus[http://www.aisf.or.jp/%7Ejaanus/]→Kujaku Omo Bosatsu の誤りかと思料します。金色孔雀王→Konjiki Kujaku-o[http://www.tctv.ne.jp/tobifudo/butuzo/28bushu/09konjiki.html]
sen.e: She is also called Makamayuri, Kujaku Butsumo, Kujaku Omo Bosatsu or Konjiki kujaku-o.
She is also called Makamayuri, Kujaku Butsumo, Kujaku Omo Bosatsu or Konjiki kujaku-o.

sen.j: 憤怒の相が特徴である明王のなかで唯一、慈悲を表した菩薩形をもつ。
sen.e: Although the charasteristic of Myoo is a fierce facial expression, she only has a Bosatsu-style face expressing mercy.
Although the characteristic of Myoo is a fierce facial expression, she has only a Bosatsu-style face expressing mercy.
Although the characteristic of Myoo is a fierce facial expression, she has only a Bosatsu-style face expressing mercy.

sen.j: クジャクの上に乗り、一面四臂の姿で表されることが多い。
sen.e: Usually, she is depicted as the one that is riding a peacock and has one face and four elbows.
Usually, she is depicted as the one that is riding a peacock and has one face and four arms.
Usually, she is depicted as the one that is riding a peacock and has one face and four arms.

sen.j: 4本の手にはそれぞれ倶縁果、吉祥果、蓮華、孔雀の尾を持つ。
sen.e: Each of four hands holds Guen-ka, Kichijo-ka (auspicious fruit), lotus and peacock's tail respectively.
sen.cmt: 倶縁果→Guen-ka[定訳不明, http://2.kaiketu-best.com/35.html]吉祥果→Kichijo-ka, auspicious fruit[http://www.buddhism-dict.net/ddb/indexes/read-ja-kk.html]
sen.e: The four hands are holding Guen-ka, Kichijo-ka (auspicious fruit), lotus and a peacock's tail, respectively.
The four hands are holding Guen-ka, Kichijo-ka (auspicious fruit), lotus and a peacock's tail, respectively.

sen.j: なお、京都・仁和寺の画像（北宋時代、国宝）のように三面六臂に表わされた像もある。
sen.e: There are some images, such as the painting image at Ninna-ji Temple Kyoto (the northern song dynasty Period, national trasure), that have three faces and six elbows.
sen.cmt: 仁和寺→Ninna-ji Temple[http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/org/ninnaji/]北宋時代→the northern song dynasty Period[Webster Online Dictionary]
sen.e: There are some images, such as the painting image at Ninna-ji Temple Kyoto (the Northern Song Dynasty period, a national treasure), that have three faces and six arms.
There are some images, such as the painting image at Ninna-ji Temple in Kyoto (the Northern Song Dynasty period, a national treasure), that have three faces and six arms.

sen.j: 孔雀は害虫やコブラなどの毒蛇を食べることから孔雀明王は「人々の災厄や苦痛を取り除く功徳」があるとされ信仰の対象となった。
sen.e: As a peacock eats bugs and poisonous snakes like copra, Kujaku Myoo was believed to do the "pious act to remove plague or pain from people"and became the object of faith.
Because a peacock eats bugs and poisonous snakes like copra, Kujaku Myoo was believed to do the "pious act of removing plague or pain from people" and therefore became an object of faith.
Because a peacock eats bugs and poisonous snakes like cobra, Kujaku Myoo was believed to do the 'pious act of removing plague or pain from people' and therefore became an object of faith.

sen.j: 後年になると孔雀明王は毒を持つ生物を食べる＝人間の煩悩の象徴である三毒（貪り・嗔り・痴行）を喰らって仏道に成就せしめる功徳がある仏という解釈が一般的になり、魔を喰らうことから大護摩に際して除魔法に孔雀明王の真言を唱える宗派も多い。
sen.e: Later on, the interpretation that Kujaku Myoo does the pious act of accomplishing Buddhism by eating poisonous living matter, in other words by eating the three kleshas that poison the heart of man(desire, ill will and ignorance) which symbolize the Bonno (earthly desires) of human being became prevalent and there are many sects that chant Shingon (mantra) of Kujaku Myoo at the rite as a charm against evil sprits.
sen.cmt: 煩悩→Bonno, earthly desires, foul passion, worldly desires[英辞郎 on the WEB]三毒→the three kleshas that poison the heart of man[http://www.eudict.com/?lang=engjpk&word=ignorance]貪り→desire[http://www.eudict.com/?lang=engjpk&word=ignorance]嗔り→ill will[http://www.eudict.com/?lang=engjpk&word=ignorance]痴行→ignorance[http://www.eudict.com/?lang=engjpk&word=ignorance]護摩→rite[Webster Online Dictionary]真言→mantra, Shingon[英辞郎 on the WEB]
sen.e: Later on, the interpretation that Kujaku Myoo performs the pious act of accomplishing Buddhism by eating poisonous living matter, in other words by eating the three kleshas that poison the heart of man (desire, ill will and ignorance), which symbolize the bonno (earthly desires) of human beings that had become prevalent; there are many sects that chant Shingon (mantra) of Kujaku Myoo at the rite as a charm against evil spirits.

Later on, the interpretation that Kujaku Myoo performs the pious act of accomplishing Buddhism by eating poisonous living matter, in other words by eating the three kleshas that poison the heart of man (desire, ill will and ignorance), which symbolize the bonno (earthly desires) of human beings that had become prevalent; there are many sects that chant Shingon (mantra) of Kujaku Myoo at the rite as a charm against evil spirits.

sen.j: また雨を予知する能力があるとされ祈雨法（雨乞い）にも用いられた。
sen.e: Further, it was believed to have the ability to predict rainfall and therfore, used on the occasion of ritual for rain.
Further, it was believed to have the ability to predict rainfall and was therefore used on certain occasions as a ritual for rain.
Further, it was believed to have the ability to predict rainfall and was therefore used on certain occasions as a ritual for rain.

sen.j: 孔雀明王を本尊としたとした密教呪法は孔雀経法とよばれる。
sen.e: The incantation of Mikkyo that uses Kujaku Myoo as the principal image is called Kujakukyoho.
The incantation of Mikkyo that uses Kujaku Myoo as the principal image is called Kujakukyoho.
The incantation of Mikkyo that uses Kujaku Myoo as the principal image is called Kujakukyoho.

sen.j: 真言密教において孔雀経法による祈願は鎮護国家の大法とされ最も重要視された。
sen.e: In the world of Shingon Mikkyo, the prayer of Kujakukyoho was emphasized the most as it was deemed as the prayer to guard the nation.
In the world of Shingon Mikkyo, the prayer of Kujakukyoho was emphasized the most as it was deemed to be a prayer to guard the nation.
In the world of Shingon Mikkyo, the prayer of Kujakukyoho was emphasized the most as it was deemed to be a prayer to guard the nation.

sen.j: 経典：大孔雀明王経（仏母大孔雀明王経）、大孔雀明王画像壇場儀軌
sen.e: Sutra : Daikujaku-myoo-kyo Sutra (Butsubo-daikujaku-myoo-kyo Sutra) and Daikujaku-myoo Gazodanjojiki.
sen.cmt: 大孔雀明王経→Daikujaku-myoo-kyo Sutra[http://21dzk.l.u-tokyo.ac.jp/INBUDS/search.php?m=trdd&usid=33064&a=]仏母大孔雀明王経→Butsubo-daikujaku-myoo-kyo Sutra[http://21dzk.l.u-tokyo.ac.jp/INBUDS/search.php?m=trdd&usid=33064&a=]大孔雀明王画像壇場儀軌→Daikujaku-myoo Gazodanjojiki[http://www10.ocn.ne.jp/~mk123456/zyko.htm]
sen.e: Sutra: Daikujaku-myoo-kyo Sutra (Butsubo-daikujaku-myoo-kyo Sutra) and Daikujaku-myoo Gazodanjojiki
Sutra: Daikujaku-myoo-kyo Sutra (Butsubo-daikujaku-myoo-kyo Sutra) and Daikujaku-myoo Gazodanjojiki

sen.j: 日本では奈良時代ごろから信仰され、創建当初の西大寺 (奈良市)金堂に安置されていたとの記録もある。
sen.e: In Japan, there is a record stating that she was worshiped during Nara Period and her image was placed at newly constructed Saidai-ji Temple Kondo (Saidai-ji Temple Golden Hall).
In Japan there is a record stating that she was worshiped during the Nara period, and her image was placed at the newly constructed Saidai-ji Temple Kondo (Saidai-ji Temple Golden Hall).
In Japan there is a record stating that she was worshiped during the Nara period, and her image was placed at the newly constructed Saidai-ji Temple Kondo (Saidai-ji Temple Golden Hall).
